results.title: Climbing plants
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Botany”.
The film provides a clear explanation of every plant’s need for light and then shows the adaptations which are developed by climbing plants to fulfil this need. Time-lapse techniques are used to illustrate the twining of stems and the growth of different kinds of tendrils. Designed for class-room use.

results.title: How our two party system operates
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Building Political Leadership”.
Dr Alfred de Grazia explains the role of political parties in the U.S.A., their history, the structure of the major American political party, voter behaviour, and functions of the parties.

results.title: Pressure groups in action
results.creator_credit: Marbury Ogle, Republic Steel Corporation and Cinecraft Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Building Political Leadership”.
Dr Marbury Ogle says that man has always organised groups to help him achieve what was beyond the capacity of one person. In America there are at least 300,000 formal and informal pressure groups, which try to direct, educate and motivate members, to win over the general public and to try to influence the government by lobbying. The lobbyist may act as a valuable informal consultant to a politician while his group may give minorities a chance to express their needs.

The Role of the Supreme Court

results.title: Our federal constitutional system
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Building Political Leadership”.
According to Dr. Ivan Hinderaker, the founders of the United States of America questioned whether they should control it. He explains how the American Constitution and the Bill of Rights came about, and claim that there are three main classifications of government: Dictatorship or Democracy? Unitary or Federal? Parliamentary or Presidential? Good use of graphics as an educational tool.

results.title: The Role of the Supreme Court
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Building Political Leadership”.
Dr David Fellman claims that the U.S. Supreme Court is unique because of its great power. The American system of government is based on the constitution and the Supreme Court is its final judge and arbiter. Dr Fellman discusses the role, organisation, jurisdiction procedures of the supreme court, and explains how it fits in with other U.S. Governmental and civil institutions

results.title: The Meaning of democracy
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Building Political Leadership”.
Dr. E E Schattschneider explains the meaning of democracy. Democracy, in his view, is a way of living justly with other people. It is a search for justice and truth. The American Bill of Rights and the system of justice are also discussed.

results.title: Greenprint for life
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Botanic man”.
Botanist and ecologist, David Bellamy, takes us deep into the Amazonian jungle to illustrate the complex ecosystems which have evolved there. The Indians, animals and plants exist in harmony, each dependent on the other in cycles of growth, decay and regrowth. Bellamy stresses the importance of this balance between man and nature and explains the adaptations plants have made in this hot, wet, dense environment to maximise photosynthesis, the by-product of which is the all important oxygen on which our world relies.

results.title: Crackpot, jackpot: Human contrasts and survival
results.brief_description:
Episode number 10 of Series “Botanic man”.
This program takes a look at the problems caused by the high energy consumption of modern countries and some possible solutions. It contrasts life in California, the inhabitants of a tower block who live in a completely controlled environment and the inhabitants of Mexico where Indians are farming land which is rich in oil and great changes are about to embrace them.

results.title: Life on the limit: cultivation and the environment
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “Botanic man”.
Highlights the problems caused by the development of agriculture, focusing on India with the agricultural revolution in Assam which caused one of the first man-made ecological disasters. As the trees were felled to make way for cultivation, the soil was unprotected and the vital minerals were eroded from the soil by the heavy rainfall. It is an example of a paradox that has plagued almost every one of the developments modern man has achieved.
